Chesser sanitizes HTML in move text. Only the following tags and attributes are preserved {(see source code)}: 
ALLOWED_TAGS = {
  "b", "i", "u", "em", "strong", "a",
  "hr", "br", "ul", "ol", "li",
  "code", "pre", "blockquote", "fenseq",
}
ALLOWED_ATTRIBUTES = {
  "a": {"href", "title", "target"},
  "fenseq": {"data-fen"},
}
Here we're using the “preformatted” <pre> block and <code> inline tags. Chesser normalizes spacing between paragraphs, HTML elements, and subvariations. This guide covers all built-in HTML tags. The custom <fenseq> tag is covered in another guide.

Alert readers will have noticed we also demonstrated hyperlink anchor tags above. <a href="https://example.com">Example!</a> Which is protectively modified during serialization: <a href="https://example.com"    rel="noopener noreferrer">Example!</a> The target attribute is allowed to open links in a new browser window or tab: target="_blank"

You can use <i> or <em> for italics, and <b> or <strong> for bold. <u>Underline</u> <hr> Horizontal Rule ➷
Unordered List <ul>:
  • Apple
  • Banana
Ordered List <ol>:
  1. Steal underwear
  2. ...
  3. Profit!
<blockquote>
There's not the mystery in ten murders that there is in one game of chess. –Sir Arthur Conan Doyle
Line<br>Breaks<br>Yo Line
Breaks
Yo

Chesser has robust subvariation and comment parsing. –Chesser’s author
Subvariations are enclosed by parentheses and comments by curly braces. Comments may also be implied when they appear outside parentheses. Type this: {Implied comment (1...e5 {{actual comment}} 2.Nf3 {{...}})} To display: Implied comment (1...e5 {actual comment} 2.Nf3 {...}) Show literal, non-subvariation parens as a comment by enclosing them in curly braces. Type this: {{{(Parenthetically speaking...)}}} To display: {(Parenthetically speaking...)} Use doubled curly braces to show a single literal brace. Type this: {{{{or}}}} To display: {{or}}

A subvar may continue directly after the mainline move. {(2.Nc3 2.Nf6)} ➡️ (2.Nc3 2.Nf6) A subvar may start with the same move as the mainline. This “root dupe” won't be displayed if there are following moves. {(1...e5 2.d4)} ➡️ (1...e5 d4) We also drop nested root dupes {(e.g. Nc6)}: {(2.Nf3 Nc6 (2...Nc6 3.Bc4))} ➡️ (2.Nf3 Nc6 (2...Nc6 3.Bc4)) Root dupes are left alone when there are no following moves: {(1...e5)} ➡️ (1...e5) Subvars may also start with mainline “sibling” moves: {(1...d5 exd5)} ➡️ (1...d5 exd5) Nested subvars may also start with siblings: {(1...c5 2.Nf3 (2.Bc4?))} ➡️ (1...c5 2.Nf3 (2.Bc4?)) Simple alternate moves: Instead of using a nested subvariation, alternate moves can be specified by making them follow a comment. There can be more than one alternate, and an alternate line may include follow-up moves. (2.Nf3 {or} 2.Nc3) (2.Nf3 {or} 2.Nc3 {or} 2.d4) (2.Nf3 {or} 2.Nc3 Nf6) When things go wrong: ❌ marks the spot where parsing failed due to incorrect or ambiguous notation. {(2.Nf3 Nc6 3.Bf4)} ➡️ (2.Nf3 Nc6 3.Bf4) The parser will attempt to interpret variations with missing or incorrect move numbers. The result may or may not resolve into a legal, navigable line. {(Nf3 Nc6 Bb5 a6)} ➡️ (Nf3 Nc6 Bb5 a6)

Use the custom <fenseq> HTML tag to specify an arbitrary starting point: 7.Bb3 O-O 8.c3 d5! If data-fen is omitted or empty, Chesser will use the starting position FEN. These are all the same: <fenseq data-fen="rnbqkbnr/…">1.d4 d5</fenseq> <fenseq data-fen="">1.d4 d5</fenseq> <fenseq>1.d4 d5</fenseq> 1.d4 d5 Clicking the ⏮️ button jumps to the specified FEN before the sequence begins. Alternation works in <fenseq> blocks, but they don’t otherwise support nesting. They’re meant to be simple, {(mostly)} flat sequences. 1.e4 e5 {or} 1.e3 d5 1.e4 e5 {or} 1...d5 2.exd5 {or} 2.e5?
See also: Basic HTML Formatting

Best by test. –Bobby Fischer
The King's Pawn Opening is the most popular first move at all levels of the game. 1.e4 opens lines to develop the Queen and the King's Bishop. It also fights for control of the center. 1.e4 directly controls d5 and f5. If White wants to develop some pieces, the most important square they control by playing 1.e4 is, in fact, the e4 square itself: as long as there's a White pawn on e4, there can't be a Black pawn on e4, which means White's g1-knight can be developed to f3 without fear of getting kicked away by a pawn and losing a tempo. Black has several ways to respond. The main idea is to find a way to prevent White from achieving or maintaining a two-pawn center with both e4 and d4. They may try to:
  • Control the d4 square.
  • Attack White's e4 pawn directly.
  • Prepare to establish their own pawn on d5.
  • Let White build a center but prepare to undermine it later.
{(See more in Wikibooks...)}

1...e5 serves to challenge White's plan of having the center squares to themselves. Of course, just like White's e4 move, e5 opens up the diagonals for Black's Bishop and Queen. While the position is still symmetrical there are few limits to where White can take the game next.

The most common move is (2.Nf3), continuing the fight for the center. A more aggressive player might also go for the King's Gambit with (2.f4). Black can take the pawn, but the gambit might allow White a quick and dangerous tactical attack. The former world chess champion, Bobby Fischer gave several great demonstrations of that opening's deadly potential.

Black will want to be familiar with 2.Qh5, where White dreams of checkmating Black with a quick Scholar's Mate. (2.Qh5 Nc6 3.Bc4 {and White hopes for something like} 3...Bc5? {or} 3...Nf6? 4.Qxf7#)

Nf3 is the classic of all classics. The Knight on f3 fights for control of the center by attacking Black's e5 pawn. It also supports a potential d2-d4 move.

It's common to develop the knight before the bishop across a wide range of openings. This is because there is usually only one good square for the knight, while the bishop has several options. We can see this in Black's most common response, Nc6. Black could also counterattack with (2...Nf6), known as the Russian Game or Petrov Defense.

Black develops the Knight to c6, defending Black's e5 pawn while also fighting for control of d4.

White can now choose between several well-known openings. The Ruy Lopez (3.Bb5), Italian Game (3.Bc4), and Scotch Game (3.d4) are all solid openings that see regular play at all levels. With the Ruy Lopez, White seeks to chase the initiative and attacks the defender of Black’s e5 pawn. In the Italian Game, the Bishop on c4 targets Black’s f7 pawn, the weakest pawn in the starting position. The Scotch Game with 3.d4 often leads to more concrete variations, with the central pawns being exchanged right away.

With this aggressive pawn advance, White looks to open up the center. (3...exd4) is played almost every time. It releases the central tension and leads to a very open game, with a lot of space for both players. (3...Nxd4{, the Lolli variation, is playable. White can trade on d4,} (4.Nxd4 exd4 5.Qxd4{, taking advantage of the fact Black has traded their Knight to centralize their Queen, or play}) (4.Nxe5)), threatening Qxd4. A few tries have been made with (3...d6{, transposing into a Philidor Defense, but this affords White a range of good options:} 4.d5{, kicking the Knight and expanding in the center is the most straightforward, or} 4.Bb5), transposing into an Old Steinitz Spanish. {(See: 3.d4 Scotch Game in Wikibooks)}
Essentially the only move. Black contests the center.
This dubious move is the most popular one at lower levels and is often employed by intermediate players as well. It allows the Queen to centralize on d4, where she's not easily attacked.

Now White can go for long castling and often launch a kingside attack. ⚔️

Some players like pushing (5...c5 {, which is good for White after} 6.Qe3 {, } 6.Qd3){, etc. Black might also play} (5...Qf6{, trying to trade queens, but after} 6.Qc4 Qc6 7.Nc3) we are generally happy to allow the queen trade in return for a strong lead in development.
This tepid move is the most popular in online games. Perhaps Black has been burned before by (5...Nf6? 6.e5!).
(6.Nc3) and other moves are fine, too.

Now c-pawn pushers might find themselves losing their d-pawn:

(8...c5? 9.Qd2 O-O 10.Bxd6!)

mainline: 1.e4 e5 2.Nf3 Nc6 3.d4 exd4 4.Nxd4 Nxd4 5.Qxd4 d6 6.Bf4 Nf6 7.Nc3 Be7 8.O-O-O O-O 9.f3

Black develops a Knight and attacks the e4-pawn, getting one step closer to castling. This move seems like the most obvious one Black can play in the Italian, but it also comes at a disadvantage of blocking the d8-h4 diagonal of the black queen.

White has several ways to proceed from this position: defend the e-pawn, usually with (4.d3), attack f7 with the aggressive (4.Ng5), or sacrifice the pawn for an open center and swift attack.

The Knight Attack!

We need to know a few things to defend against this very common move at lower levels. {(The top guys play it occasionally, too. Perhaps to mix things up with an irrational position.)}

This Romantic move is an attack on f7 with the Bishop and Knight, taking advantage of the fact that Black gave up control of g5 and cannot castle yet. However, it is unprincipled to attack before having finished development. Siegbert Tarrasch slammed the move as “bungling,” reflecting the classical view that early attacks without development are suspect.

White might be hoping for the "Fried Liver" attack:

(4...d5 5.exd5 Nxd5 6.Nxf7! Kxf7 7.Qf3 Ke6)

And while an engine might be able to defend this, it’s not a position most humans will enjoy playing.

Fearful beginners will sometimes play <fenseq data-fen="r1bqkbnr/pppp1ppp/2n5/4p3/2B1P3/5N2/PPPP1PPP/RNBQK2R b KQkq - 3 3">3...h6 {to prevent this nasty incursion, but it passively loses a tempo to} 4.d4!</fenseq>, and while not losing outright, it starts us off on our back foot. It's better—and more fun—to learn the lines so that we can happily engage with this aggression.

There is only one principled response to the Knight incursion: (4...d5!)
Black has one principled response that meets the attack head-on.

mainline: 1.e4 e5 2.Nf3 Nc6 3.Bc4 Nf6 4.Ng5 d5 5.exd5 Na5 6.Bb5+ c6 7.dxc6 bxc6
